security: Releasing the names of individuals presently under cover, whether active or separated employees, would breach Agency commitments to these individuals and our obligations to cover providers. Revealing covert relationships with cover providers would paralyze Agency operations, which in turn could severely damage national security.
summary: A memorandum from the Chief of the Office of Central Cover objecting to the release of names of CIA personnel under cover to the JFK Assassination Records Review Board, citing risks to personal safety, ongoing operations, and relationships with cover providers.
summary_one_paragraph: This secret memorandum, dated December 7, 1995, from Eric L. Qualkenbush, Chief of the Office of Central Cover, to the JFK Assassination Records Review Board, expresses strong objections to the release of CIA personnel names currently or formerly under cover. Qualkenbush argues this would violate secrecy agreements, endanger individuals and their second careers, compromise other employees and sources, and jeopardize relationships with cover providers like the Department of State and private sector entities, potentially paralyzing Agency operations and damaging national security; he proposes using pseudonyms or generic job descriptions instead of true names.
title: Proposed CIA Name Release
sender: Eric L. Qualkenbush, Chief, Office of Central Cover
